awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Empirical Analysis of Social Network with Unreported Links
awd_abstract_narration:
In many social-economic contexts, an individual's behavior depends on his own characteristics, as well as the outcome and characteristics of others. Such dependence called a link; individuals with links are neighbors and a collection of neighbors is referred to as a network. A social network consists of linked individuals. This commonly occurs in applied economic research since links are often not well measured in the research data. This project will estimate the effects of social networks on individual outcomes when the links are either misclassified or not reported in data. The method proposed in this project is adaptable to a wide range of social networks. It also provides a general method for comparing various types of social effects given group characteristics. The project offers an efficient approach for policy analyses that resolves challenges due to data problems or measurement errors in network links. The results of this project provide a way to measure the effects of policies when there is no information on network structure. The results of this project will have a significant impact on empirical research on social networks and policies such as education. This will improve efficiency in business and policy decision making and, in the process, lead to improved well-being of U.S. citizens. 

This project identifies and estimates social network models when network links are either misclassified or unobserved. It first derives and characterizes conditions under which some misclassification of links does not interfere with the consistency or asymptotic properties of standard instrumental variable estimators of social effects. It then constructs a consistent estimator of social effects in a model where network links are not observed. This method does not require repeated observations of individual network members. The project will apply this estimator to data from Tennessee's Student/Teacher Achievement Ratio (STAR) Project. Without observing the latent network in each classroom, the research identifies and estimate peer and contextual effects on students' performance in mathematics. The results suggest that peer effects tend to be larger in bigger classes, and that increasing peer effects significantly improve students' average test scores. The results of this research will help businesses and policy makers account for social effects in decision making hence improve the living standards of U.S. citizens.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Under this grant, I have published three articles on peer-reviewed academic journals:

  • "Uncovering Heterogeneous Social Effects in Binary Choices" (Co-authors: Zhongjian Lin and Ning Yu. Published on The Journal of Econometrics, Vol 222, No 2, 2021)
  • "Social Networks with Unobserved Links" (Co-authors: Arthur Lewbel and Xi Qu. Published on The Journal of Political Economy, Vol 131, No. 4, 2023)
  • "Ignoring Measurement Errors in Social Networks" (Co-authors: Arthur Lewbel and Xi Qu. Published on The Econometrics Journal, December 2023)

I have also completed two working papers:

  • "Identification and Estimation of Large Network Games with Private Link Information" (Co-author: Hulya Eraslan. Under 2nd round review at The International Economic Review)
  • "Estimation of Social Networks with Link Misclassification" (Co-authors: Arthur Lewbel and Xi Qu, in preparation for submission to an academic journal)

I have presented these papers at many U.S. and international academic institutions and conferences (including at Northwestern University, University of Pennsylvania, annual Econometric Society meetings, etc).

 

 

  • For estimating network effects in social groups without link information from the sample, we introduced a novel approach that exploits how multiple covariates interact with the same network structure to influence individual outcomes. We used the method to analyze students performance from Tennessee elementary schools. The social effect estimators are robust, and provides some adjustment to those reported earlier in the literature (under more restrictive modeling assumptions, such as linear in means). The final product was published at The Journal of Political Economy.
  • For estimatiing network effects in social groups, when the data reports a noisy measure of actual network structure (e.g., due to random link misclassificaiton, or missing links), we propose a new method of adjusted 2SLS, which solves the issue of bias in estimation in the conventional 2SLS method. This working paper has been presented at multiple academic institutions, and international conferences, and is currently in preparation for submission to an academic journal.
  • For insights about when existing method for estimating network effects (which assumes perfect observation of link status) could remain valid despite imperfect data on links, we provide formal, technical conditions on the order of link measure errors. We also provide a suite of practical examples to help empirical researchers understand when those conditions can be satisfied in realistic settings. The final output was published at The Econometrics Journal.
  • For addressing related questions for qualitative responses (as opposed to linear models with continuous ooutcomes), we (co-authors and I) have two sets of results: introduced and estimte a new theoretical model where group memberes have private information about links and make simultaneous decisions; revisit an existing model of binary response with social interactions, but propose new robust methods for estimation that allows for link measurement issues. For both tasks, we are able to introdue new methodology that are easy to implement in practical applications, culminating in useful empirical findings. The first set of results are in a working paper that is under 2nd round review at The International Economic Review, and the second set of results have been published at The Journal of Econometrics.
